episode.title: Tira, Bombay Shaving Co., Inde Wild | WTF is Fueling India’s Beauty & Skincare Revolution? | Ep. 25
episode.framing: Three founders leading India’s skincare wave – Bhakti Modi (Tira), Shantanu Deshpande (Bombay Shaving Company), and Diipa Khosla (Inde Wild) join Nikhil Kamath to share the highs and lows of building beauty and skincare brands and the trends shaping this booming industry.

guests.name: Bhakti Modi
guests.bio: CEO of Tira, Reliance Retail Ventures Limited's beauty platform.

guests.name: Diipa Khosla
guests.bio: Founder of Inde Wild, a globally recognized beauty and wellness brand leveraging Ayurvedic principles.

guests.name: Shantanu Deshpande
guests.bio: Founder of Bombay Shaving Company, a men's grooming brand in India.

insights.title: Community Building through Shared Values and Co-creation
insights.content: Building an authentic community based on shared values is a key competitive advantage that cannot be easily copied. Founders should start small, host events, and truly engage with their customers through feedback mechanisms (surveys, focus groups, customer service) to co-create the brand experience and foster loyalty.
insights.context: Diipa explains how Inde Wild's community strategy is built on co-creation, starting with pre-launch surveys involving thousands of followers and maintaining a highly engaged customer service approach.
insights.speaker: Diipa Khosla
insights.action_item: Infuse community engagement into every aspect of the brand, treating followers as 'educated besties' to build an emotional connection and ensure repeated purchases.

insights.title: Identify a 'Hero Product' that Solves a Niche Problem
insights.content: A successful D2C brand should launch with one strong 'hero product' that addresses a specific, high-demand problem in the market. The example of Mamaearth's mosquito repellent, which initially generated a large portion of its revenue, illustrates how a niche solution can build initial scale.
insights.context: Shantanu and Diipa discuss Mamaearth's initial success with a mosquito repellent for kids, demonstrating a strong first product strategy before diversifying into other categories like onion hair products.
insights.speaker: Shantanu Deshpande
insights.action_item: Focus initial capital and marketing efforts on a single product that solves a real problem for the target audience to establish brand presence and achieve product-market fit.

insights.title: Fragrance Wardrobing Trend
insights.content: A significant trend in fragrances is 'perfume wardrobing,' where consumers (especially Gen Z) own multiple fragrances to match different moods or occasions. This increases per-consumer purchase frequency and drives demand for smaller SKUs (10ml, 15ml, 20ml).
insights.context: Shantanu explains the shift from having one or two signature scents to having a 'wardrobe' of fragrances for different scenarios like work, date nights, or social outings.
insights.speaker: Shantanu Deshpande

insights.title: Define an Authentic 'Why' for Storytelling
insights.content: Authentic storytelling requires a clear 'why' for starting the brand. While a white space analysis is necessary, an emotional or personal mission behind the brand's creation (e.g., solving a specific problem or fulfilling a personal need) is critical for building a long-term, genuine connection with the consumer and community.
insights.context: Nikhil roleplays as a founder named Dilip to explore how to create a brand narrative based on a perceived market problem, leading to a discussion on authenticity.
insights.speaker: Diipa Khosla
insights.action_item: New founders must define their authentic brand mission (their 'why') before focusing on marketing tactics. The storytelling must reflect genuine values to avoid being perceived as opportunistic.

insights.title: Don't: Use Sarcastic or Negative Branding for Beauty Products
insights.content: While content can be tongue-in-cheek or sarcastic, the product name itself should avoid negative connotations. Beauty products aim to make people feel good about themselves, and a negative brand name (like 'Stench' or 'Gutter') undermines this core value and will likely alienate consumers, making it difficult to build a community.
insights.context: Nikhil suggests satirical product names like 'Stench' for a fragrance brand. Bhakti and Diipa advise against this, stating it breaks category codes and contradicts the purpose of beauty products.
insights.speaker: Bhakti Modi
insights.action_item: Maintain positive reinforcement in core branding elements (like product names) to align with the self-improvement/self-expression nature of the beauty industry.

insights.title: Leverage Layering and Blending Trends for Cross-Selling
insights.content: Fragrance layering (mixing two different scents) is a growing trend, popularized by celebrities and influencers. Brands can capitalize on this by selling fragrance combinations and instructing consumers on how to create unique scents, effectively increasing cross-selling opportunities for different SKUs.
insights.context: The discussion references Shah Rukh Khan's technique of layering fragrances, which created a surge in demand and new product development to mimic his combination. This strategy allows consumers to customize their scent and increases a brand's average order value.
insights.speaker: Shantanu Deshpande
insights.action_item: Create fragrance sets or bundles based on layering combinations to capitalize on the customization trend and increase sales per customer.

insights.title: Fragrance Market Trends: Gourmand and Indian Ingredients
insights.content: Discussion on emerging trends in the fragrance market, including: gourmand (food-inspired) scents like vanilla, pistachio, and glazed jalebi; the significance of Kannauj as India's 'Grasse' (perfume capital); and the use of native Indian ingredients like jasmine and rose by global luxury brands like Chanel.
insights.context: The guests discuss the popularity of food-related fragrances and highlight the opportunity to create Indian-centric scents.
insights.speaker: Nikhil Kamath

insights.title: Do: Emphasize 'Clean' Fragrances that Last
insights.content: For new fragrance brands, it's crucial to address the Indian market's key concern: longevity in a hot climate. While consumers demand 'clean' ingredients and reduced alcohol content, brands must innovate to ensure the fragrance lasts throughout the day, as essential oil-based fragrances often wear off too quickly.
insights.context: Diipa and Bhakti discuss the challenge of balancing the 'clean fragrance' trend (reducing alcohol) with the Indian consumer's demand for long-lasting scents, which often requires higher concentration.
insights.speaker: Bhakti Modi
insights.action_item: Innovate on fragrance formulations to provide high longevity in a hot climate while maintaining clean ingredient standards for the health-conscious consumer.

quotes.quote_text: But at indē wild, everything we do starts and ends with community. And I mean in every aspect.
quotes.author: Diipa Khosla

quotes.quote_text: Even in our bio till today, it says, "Co-created by you."
quotes.author: Diipa Khosla

quotes.quote_text: This entire segment, basically, between 1,000 to 10,000, for the grabs. Like, it's empty.
quotes.author: Shantanu Deshpande
quotes.description: Explaining the price gap and opportunity in the masstige fragrance market.

quotes.quote_text: Today, a 25-year-old Bombay Shaving Company employee has... Is buying three new fragrances a month.
quotes.author: Shantanu Deshpande
quotes.description: Illustrating the trend of 'perfume wardrobing' and high consumption in the fragrance market.

quotes.quote_text: If I have to simplify what a community is, it is a group of people who have certain shared values that they can come together and speak about.
quotes.author: Bhakti Modi

quotes.quote_text: I'm telling-- You started off saying women. Then why do you keep thinking of Dilpreet? No, but, tell me one thing. You want to build a fragrance brand... Yeah. For women. Your issue is that you don't want them to go to, like, ten fragrances, and buy Bella Vita-- No, I don't want that. But you can yourself create-- You can do it. You sell it to the consumers saying, 'Hey, you take this fragrance. Great, you like it on its own. Amazing. But you take this plus this, and now you've got a fragrance, especially for you. And I'm telling you how to create it.'
quotes.author: Nikhil Kamath
quotes.description: Nikhil challenges the layering idea and suggests cross-selling layered combinations.

quotes.quote_text: It's like the Grasse of India. It's like this perfume... Perfumers there... in the thousands.
quotes.author: Shantanu Deshpande

quotes.quote_text: I think it's just creativity. About self-expression. It's individuality. Yeah, self-expression.
quotes.author: Bhakti Modi
quotes.description: Bhakti's perspective on layering and consumer customization.
